title: pr-3cf.2 COMPLETED
description:
Task pr-3cf.2 (Income Modeling: Throughput and Scenarios) is complete.

Created: research/03-income-modeling.md

Summary:
- Throughput analysis: 2,000-2,500 words/hour sustainable for clean fiction
- Three income scenarios modeled over 3 years
- Sensitivity analysis on rates, throughput, and capacity utilization
- Real-world constraints: seasonal variability, burnout limits, client acquisition challenges

- 3-year minimum timeline to full-time income

title: Living Like RyÅkan in the Modern World - Master Epic
description:
Master epic for comprehensive research and design of a practical modern-day life model inspired by RyÅkan.

DELIVERABLES:
- /reports/living_like_ryokan_in_the_modern_world.pdf
- /reports/methodology.md
- /reports/references.md

TARGET: Modern proofreader with two children, limited screen time, simple living, quiet contemplative rhythm.

title: Convoy A: RyÅkan Historical & Scholarly Research
description:
DEEP RESEARCH on RyÅkan's actual life, not myth.

REQUIRED RESEARCH:
- Primary sources on RyÅkan (poetry, calligraphy, letters)
- Secondary scholarly sources (academic analysis)
- Historical context of Edo-period monastic life
- Scholarly commentary distinguishing fact from hagiography

OUTPUTS:
1. Historical timeline of RyÅkan's life
2. Analysis of his daily rhythms and practices
3. Relationship to work, writing, solitude
4. Relationship to possessions and material needs
5. Relationship to children and villagers
6. Relationship to time

Strip away mythology. Cite sources. No pop-spiritual summaries.

title: Convoy B: Principle Extraction & Analysis
description:
Extract and analyze core principles from RyÅkan's life.

PRINCIPLES TO IDENTIFY AND EXPLAIN:
- voluntary simplicity
- unforced rhythm
- non-instrumental creativity
- playful seriousness
- radical sufficiency
- acceptance of imperfection
- relationship to time and productivity

For each principle:
- Define in plain language (no jargon)
- Provide textual evidence from sources
- Distinguish essential from incidental
- Note what governed his approach to work, solitude, play, writing

DEPENDS ON: Convoy A research outputs.

title: Convoy C: Modern Constraint Modeling
description:
Explicitly model constraints of modern life that affect applying RyÅkan's principles.

CONSTRAINTS TO ANALYZE:
- Paid work as proofreader (income necessity)
- Two children requiring care and presence
- Housing in modern American society
- Legal and economic realities
- Technology saturation
- Health insurance, retirement, education
- Social expectations

DO NOT minimize these constraints.
Be brutally honest about what cannot be ignored.

title: Convoy D: Lifestyle Translation Design
description:
Translate RyÅkan principles to modern life honestly.

FOR EACH PRINCIPLE from Convoy B:
- What stays the same
- What must change
- What cannot transfer at all

This is translation, not imitation. Be honest about:
- Which principles require complete reinterpretation
- Which must be abandoned
- What 'radical sufficiency' means with kids and mortgage

Output: Detailed translation matrix with rationale for each decision.

DEPENDS ON: Convoy B principles, Convoy C constraints.

title: Convoy E: Schedule & Rhythm Design
description:
Design concrete daily/weekly schedules and rhythms.

DELIVERABLES:
1. Daily schedule (weekday)
2. Daily schedule (weekend)
3. Weekly rhythm patterns
4. Seasonal variations (winter vs summer)
5. Work rhythm for proofreading
6. Screen use rules (specific limits)
7. Reading and writing practice schedules
8. Walking and embodied time allocation
9. A concrete 'Week in the Life' example

Technology boundaries:
- What technology is kept
- What is excluded
- Why these boundaries matter
- Tie to existing detox plans in reports/

No idealized perfection. This must be livable.

DEPENDS ON: Convoy D translation decisions.

title: Convoy F: Family & Work Integration
description:
Design family life and work integration.

FAMILY INTEGRATION:
- How simplicity works with children
- How play replaces consumption
- How presence replaces busyness
- How values are modeled, not taught

WORK INTEGRATION:
- Relationship to money (enough, not accumulation)
- Relationship to productivity
- Household simplicity principles
- Success defined as sufficiency, presence, continuity, quiet joy

RISKS AND FAILURE MODES:
- Where this breaks down
- How to notice drift
- How to return without guilt
- What to do when money, energy, or time tighten

DEPENDS ON: Convoy E schedule/rhythm design.

title: Convoy G: Report Synthesis & QA
description:
Synthesize all research into final deliverables.

PRIMARY DELIVERABLE:
/reports/living_like_ryokan_in_the_modern_world.pdf

SUPPORTING:
- /reports/methodology.md
- /reports/references.md

STRUCTURE (10 SECTIONS):
1. RyÅkan: The Actual Life (historical facts)
2. Core Principles (extracted and explained)
3. Constraints of Modern Life (explicit list)
4. Translation, Not Imitation (principle mapping)
5. A Modern 'RyÅkan-Adjacent' Life Model
6. Family Life Integration
7. Technology Boundaries
8. A Week in the Life (concrete example)
9. Risks, Failure Modes, and Course Correction
10. What Success Looks Like

QUALITY BAR:
If any recommendation feels romanticized, ignores economic reality, assumes solitude without responsibility, or substitutes aesthetics for practice - REVISE IT.

Must be livable for years, not inspiring for a weekend.

DEPENDS ON: All previous convoys.

- Modern shops successfully using hand tools
- What products they make
- Pricing reality
- Physical sustainability

Output: Research notes with sources

title: task
description:
dispatched_by: mayor

Research:
- Individual craftspeople earning a living today
- What they actually make
- How they price
- Physical demands
- Business models (commission vs standard, etc.)
- Avoid influencer/YouTube narratives

Output: Research notes with sources

title: task
description:
dispatched_by: mayor

Design a realistic training program:
- Foundational hand-tool skills (sharpening, sawing, planing, chiseling, joinery)
- Project-based skill building
- Progressive difficulty
- Time-to-competence estimates
- Recommended practice schedule
- What must be mastered BEFORE taking paid work
- Common beginner errors and injury risks

Structure as 1-3 year curriculum.

Deliverable: /reports/hand_tool_woodworking_training_program.pdf

title: task
description:
dispatched_by: mayor

Tasks:
- Identify viable product categories for hand-tool production
- Evaluate time per piece, pricing ceilings, customer type
- Recommend 1-2 core offerings + optional secondary offerings
- Build conservative pricing models
- Avoid underpricing craft labor

Deliverable: Product strategy section for business plan

title: task
description:
dispatched_by: mayor

Design a shop for one-car garage or smaller:
- Essential hand tools with rationale
- Minimal power tools for dimensioning only
- Workbench design
- Storage strategy  
- Dust/noise considerations
- Startup cost estimates
- Ongoing maintenance costs

Explicitly exclude unnecessary tools.

Deliverable: Shop design section for business plan
close_reason: Shop design complete. Created reports/shop_design_garage.md with comprehensive one-car garage hand-tool woodworking shop design including: tool lists with costs, workbench specifications, layout diagram, phased acquisition strategy, and explicit exclusions. Total startup: $4,050-$7,730. Annual maintenance: $210-$415.

title: task
description:
dispatched_by: mayor

Build models showing:
- Hours per week at the bench
- Pieces per month
- Gross revenue per piece
- Annual gross revenue scenarios (conservative, realistic, optimistic)

Answer explicitly:
- How many hours/week required to reach $60k?
- Where do bottlenecks appear?
- What breaks first (body, time, market)?

Deliverable: Revenue model section for viability study

title: task

Deliverable: Risk section for viability study

title: task
description:
